children.name: when sb lives for a very long time
longevity
children.definition: /lɒnˈdʒevɪti, lɒnˈdʒevətiǁlɑːn-, lɔːn-/  formal:
examples: ▪ The more successful we are at prolonging longevity, the more it will cost us in elderly care costs.
▪ the disparity in the longevity of the sexes
health and longevity
▪ The people of this village enjoy good health and longevity.
somebody’s longevity
▪ He attributes his longevity to ‘a simple diet and a glass of wine every day’.

children.name: long
children.definition: /lɒŋǁlɔːŋ/  continuing for a long time:

children.name: dài ,lâu
examples: ▪ The play was good, but it was a little too long.
▪ He died after a long illness.
▪ It’s a long flight - 15 hours.

children.name: lengthy
children.definition: /ˈleŋθi/  a lengthyprocessordelaytakes a long time so that you have to wait before you can do something:

children.name: kéo dài , dài dòng
examples: ▪ She died of natural causes after a lengthy illness.
▪ The runways have reopened, but travelers have been warned to expect lengthy delays.

children.name: lengthy process/procedure etc
examples: ▪ He was indicted on drug charges after a lengthy investigation by the US Drug Enforcement Administration.
▪ The procedures for bringing a body back for burial are lengthy and complex.
▪ Creating a new network system is a lengthy process.

children.name: long-running
children.definition: /ˌlɒŋ ˈrʌnɪŋ◂ǁˌlɔːŋ-/  a long-runningeventorperformanceis one that continues for a very long time:

children.name: kéo dài
examples: ▪ The action is the latest in a long-running battle between the US and Canada relating to Cuban relations.
▪ The proposal would end a long-running dispute between the Internal Revenue and the petroleum producers.
▪ The long-running musical "Jesus Christ Superstar' is to close after more than 3,000 performances.

children.name: long-standing
children.definition: /ˌlɒŋ ˈstændɪŋ◂ǁˌlɔːŋ-/  a long-standingsituation,agreement, orarrangementhas continued for a long time and is likely to continue for a long time in the future :

children.name: kéo dài
examples: ▪ Motorola has a long-standing agreement to provide at least one week’s training to all new employees.
▪ The area is populated by Kurdish rebels who have long-standing grievances against Hussein.
▪ GM maintains a long-standing policy of not commenting on market speculation and rumour.

children.name: lasting
children.definition: /ˈlɑːstɪŋǁˈlæs-/  strong enough or great enough to continue for a long time:

children.name: bền vững, lâu dài
examples: ▪ The speech could do lasting damage to US--German relations.
▪ Japan’s creation of a Western-style economy has been the country’s lasting achievement.

children.name: lasting effect/impact etc
examples: ▪ His next book is about the lasting effects of the Vietnam war.

children.name: lasting peace/friendship/agreement etc
examples: ▪ Until we all give up violence, there cannot possibly be lasting peace in the world.

children.name: leave/make a lasting impression
examples: ▪ The incident left a lasting impression on the young girl.

children.name: lifelong
children.definition: /ˈlaɪflɒŋǁ-lɔːŋ/  continuing for all ofsomeone’s life- use this aboutrelationships,interestsandfeelingsetc :

children.name: kéo dài suốt cả đời ai đó
examples: ▪ She first visited Ireland when she was ten, and developed a lifelong interest in the country.
▪ Depression has been a lifelong struggle for me.

children.name: lifelong ambition/dream etc
examples: ▪ According to his biographers, he had a lifelong ambition to make money.
▪ For many people, owning their own business is a lifelong goal.

children.name: lifelong member/resident/friend etc
examples: ▪ Virginia Maples, a lifelong resident, praised the town for its neighborliness.
▪ Alvin met the poet Hughes, who became a lifelong friend and confidante.

children.name: prolonged
children.definition: /prəˈlɒŋdǁ-ˈlɔːŋd/  continuing for a long time, or longer than you expected:

children.name: kéo dài
examples: ▪ How are you going to explain your prolonged absence?

children.name: ▪ a prolonged and bloody battle for independence
examples: ▪ Studies show that prolonged exposure to maternal depression can result in childhood mood disorders.

children.name: lingering
children.definition: /ˈlɪŋgərɪŋ/  lingering doubts, hopes, or otherfeelingscontinue for a long time, especially long after aparticularevent:

children.name: kéo dài ( cảm xúc )
examples: ▪ She had a lingering sense of guilt for some time after breaking off her relationship with Henry.
▪ For years, Mexico’s primary feeling toward the US was one of lingering resentment.
▪ What will be the lingering images of the Sydney Olympic Games?
▪ If he had any lingering doubts about the marriage, he did not show it.

children.name: enduring
children.definition: /ɪnˈdjʊərɪŋǁ-ˈdʊə-/  an enduring feeling, memory, influence, quality or relationship continues for a long time:

children.name: lâu dài , bền vững
examples: ▪ His childhood experiences had an enduring influence on his work.
▪ My most enduring memory of my father is watching him clean his rifle.
▪ The friendships formed in her schooldays proved to be the most enduring.
▪ Cartoons have a universal and enduring appeal.

children.name: abiding
children.definition: /əˈbaɪdɪŋ/ formalan abidingfeeling,belief, orinterestcontinues for a long time and is not likely to change :

children.name: vĩnh cửu , trường tồn
examples: ▪ She had a basic and abiding belief in democratic systems.
▪ As a boy he had had an abiding curiosity about how things worked.
▪ The internal security of his country was the President’s other abiding concern.
▪ His father had an abiding interest in nature.

children.name: chronic
children.definition: /ˈkrɒnɪkǁˈkrɑː-/  a chronicillnessor badsituationcontinues for a very long time or is permanent :
examples: ăn sâu
▪ China has a chronic shortage of capital, so it must encourage saving.
▪ the chronic decay of the inner city areas
▪ We need to take steps to counter the chronic decline in our export market.
▪ He suffers from chronic asthma.
chronically[adverb]
▪ care of the chronically ill

children.name: art, writing, ideas etc that last for a long time
timeless
children.definition: /ˈtaɪmləs/  music, literature, art etc, that is timeless still seems important and interesting even though it was written or made a long time ago:

children.name: ko bị tác động của thời gian, tồn tại mãi với thời gian
examples: ▪ Crosby’s ‘It Ain’t Necessarily So’ remains a timeless classic.
▪ In the south-west of England, the scenery is timeless and unmistakably agricultural.

children.name: timeless appeal/quality
examples: ▪ Shakespeare’s plays have a timeless appeal to all audiences.
▪ If a song is good enough, it has a timeless quality.

children.name: immortal
children.definition: /ɪˈmɔːʳtl/  immortal words, lines etc are famous and are remembered for a long time after they are written or spoken:
examples: bất hủ, bất tử
▪ In the immortal words of Henry Ford, ‘History is bunk.’
▪ J.M. Barrie’s immortal tale of Peter Pan

children.name: classic
children.definition: /ˈklæsɪk/  a classic book,film, design etc is one that is important or special and remains popular for a long time:

children.name: kinh điển
examples: ▪ The Coca-Cola bottle is one of the classic designs of our century.

children.name: ▪ the classic Bogart version of ‘The Maltese Falcon’
examples: ▪ ‘Jane Eyre’ is Bronte’s classic novel of courage in the face of despair.
▪ Professor Carey wrote the classic account of early explorations in Africa and Asia.

children.name: long-drawn-out
children.definition: /ˌlɒŋ drɔːn ˈaʊt◂ǁˌlɔːŋ-/  a long-drawn-out process continues for a long time, is verytiring, and probably continues for longer than it needs to:

children.name: quá dài
examples: ▪ The long-drawn-out campaigns that precede every election in the US have already begun.
▪ This war is too one-sided to be very long-drawn-out.
▪ Netscape faces a long-drawn-out battle with software giant Microsoft.
▪ Building up a successful herd is a long-drawn out process of careful buying and breeding.

children.name: long-winded
children.definition: /ˌlɒŋ ˈwɪndd◂ǁˌlɔːŋ-/  aspeechor piece ofwritingthat is long-winded is too long and therefore boring or difficult to understand:

children.name: dài dòng, lê thê
examples: ▪ Jacques launched into a long-winded explanation that left us just as confused as before.
▪ Her letters do tend to be a bit long-winded.
▪ I’m sick of reading badly-written and long-winded scripts by candidates who should know better.

children.name: protracted
children.definition: /prəˈtræktɪd, prəˈtræktəd/  something unpleasant that is protracted continues for a long time, which makes itworsethanusual :

children.name: bị kéo dài
examples: ▪ After a bloody and protracted struggle, the ‘Mau-Mau’ fighters forced Britain to grant independence.
▪ This marks the first day of what is likely to be a protracted and bitter courtroom battle.

children.name: ▪ There was a protracted silence, after which Lydia said quietly, ‘I’m to inherit all the money -- you’ll get nothing.’
interminable
children.definition: /ɪnˈtɜːʳmɪnəbəl, ɪnˈtɜːʳmənəbəl/ formalcontinuing for a very long time so that it becomesboringand you becomeimpatient:
examples: interminably[adverb]
▪ The first course took an interminably long time to arrive.
▪ He paused interminably after each question we asked him.

children.name: không cùng , vô tận
examples: ▪ The ride back to the city seemed interminable.
▪ What’s the reason for all these interminable delays?
▪ She wasn’t looking forward to the interminable winter nights, alone in the cabin.
▪ He launched into an interminable monologue about his last therapy session.

children.name: drag on
children.definition: /ˌdræg ˈɒn/  to continue for too long and so becomeboringorannoying:

children.name: kéo dài
examples: ▪ Despair grew as the war dragged on.
▪ Presidential campaigns seem to drag on forever.
▪ If the stalemate drags on, there could be serious consequences for the town’s population.

children.name: drag on for weeks/years etc
examples: ▪ Lawsuits about titles to land often drag on for years without settlement.
▪ The fighting dragged on for another two years before a settlement was finally reached.

children.name: drag on into October/2002/next year etc
examples: ▪ Analysts fear the downturn will drag on into next year.

children.name: drag on until 1945/2.00 a.m. etc
examples: ▪ The meeting dragged on until late afternoon.

children.name: take ages
children.definition: /years/forever etc/ˌteɪk ˈeɪdʒz/  to takemuchlongerthan seemsreasonable:
examples: ▪ Getting visas to visit America seemed to take ages.
▪ The problem with letters is that they always get lost or take forever to arrive.
▪ It’ll take days to sort this mess out.

children.name: take somebody ages/years/forever etc
examples: ▪ It took me ages to get all that washing done.
▪ It took Josephine months to finish writing her dissertation.

children.name: to continue for longer than was planned or expected
run on
children.definition: /ˌrʌn ˈɒn/ informalto last for a long time, especially longer than expected or planned:

children.name: kéo dài lâu quá
examples: ▪ Don’t allow meetings to run on; set an agenda and stick to it.
▪ Business lunches do tend to run on sometimes.
▪ Sorry, I’m running on a bit. What did you want to say?

children.name: overrun/run over
children.definition: /ˌəʊvəˈrʌn, ˌrʌn ˈəʊvəʳ/  if an activity such as ameetingorgameoverruns or runs over, it continues longer than it is supposed to do :

children.name: kéo dài quá lâu
examples: ▪ The meeting is going to overrun so we’d better find out what time they close the building.
▪ If the ceremony runs over, I’ll switch to Channel 17.

children.name: overrun by 10 minutes/an hour/two days etc
examples: ▪ The scenes were cut because the preceding programme overran by 10 minutes.

children.name: run over time
examples: ▪ Well, what do you know? We’ve run over time, and there’s no time for questions.

children.name: prolong
children.definition: /prəˈlɒŋǁ-ˈlɔːŋ/  to make something such as a feeling, process or activity last longer:

children.name: kéo dài
examples: ▪ He asked her another question just to prolong the conversation.
▪ Users turn to the drug in the belief that it prolongs and enhances sex.
▪ It seems he’s eager to prolong his trial for as long as possible.
▪ A heart transplant might prolong his life for a few years.

children.name: extend
children.definition: /ɪkˈstend/  to add extra time to something that had alimiton the amount of time it could last:

children.name: nới rộng, mở rộng
examples: ▪ I’ll have to ask the bank to extend the repayment time on my loan.
▪ TV coverage of the match had to be extended when it went into extra time.
▪ These cleaning devices are meant to extend the life of your cassettes.

children.name: extend something to February/next year etc
examples: ▪ The current contract expires in December, but will be extended to February 2004.

children.name: drag out
children.definition: /ˌdræg ˈaʊt/  to make aboringorunpleasantactivity or piece of work last much longer than necessary, especially because you gain some advantage by doing this:
examples: kéo dài , câu
drag something out
▪ There was really no need to drag the meeting out that long.
drag out something
▪ The protests could actually drag out the proceedings.

children.name: spin out
children.definition: /ˌspɪn ˈaʊt/  Britishinformaltodeliberatelymake an activity last longer than necessary especially so that itfillsthetimeavailable:
examples: kéo dài ( cho đủ với thời gian đã định )
spin something out
▪ Well, the lawyers always spin it out, don’t they -- that’s how they make their money!
spin out something
▪ We were paid by the hour, so I spun out the work for as long as I could.

children.name: eke out
children.definition: /ˌiːk ˈaʊt/  to make yourmoneyorfoodlast as long as possible by spending or using it carefully:

children.name: eke out something
examples: ▪ I pictured her trying to eke out her money to last to the end of the month.

children.name: eke something out
examples: ▪ We watered down the wine so as to eke it out for the remainder of the evening.

children.name: eke out a living/existence : kéo dài, duy trì sự sống
examples: ▪ She eked out a miserable living as a washer woman.
